Good for ending a meal. Strong taste after having an Ale and a Trappiste. Neither sweet nor bitter

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours an opaque black with big light brown head sticking all the way up the glass. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, oats and toast. Flavours are made up of mild-medium bitterness, chocolate, coffee, roasted malts. Fantastic for a stout, only thing that would make it better is making it an imperial or even just the abv up a bit.

I had been counting the days to try this iconic (and CANADIAN!!!) oatmeal stout. Poured oily black, black as a shoe, with a thick dark tan head, building up and staying there for a long time. A 5 for appearance. The aroma, however, was not as perfect. Nice, port, but too much of that olive, leathery tone of North American hoppy stouts on the way. When biting through the head (which still persisted, like a dry pumice stone), the coffee scent invades our nostrils, and only then you get a bit of chocolate. Flavour was much more mellow though, more of what I expected from an oatmeal stout. Dark chocolates, an excessive level of coffee and the roasted malts, so smooth and sweet. Unfortunately it lets through too much of the alcohol, in the end. The flavours were well packed into a round, smooth texture, a lot creamier than I came to expect after that first whiff. Another 5 for the palate. Good, of course, but Id never give a "100" to this beer.

21st December 2010BBE Oct 2009! Opaque black beer, good mid brown head. Smooth palate with mild carbonation. Mild oxidisation, fades quickly. Mild dark malts, minerals. Dark chocolate powder. Subtle tangy fruits underneath. Trace of lactose. Carbonated bite in the finish. Not bad.

From the 11/2012 3R6P tasting. +++ Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured thick and black with a small dark brown head that faded and left decent lacing. The aroma was anise, port wine, wood and vanilla. The flavor was port wine, vanilla, cream, faint toasty malts and had a bitter and tart undertone. Long port wine and vanilla finish. Moderately full bodied and creamy.

Bottle via StateLine... Not sure how old this bottle is but its been sitting around for at least a year. Great pour... monster mocha colored head. Black in color. Nose of chalk, ash, roasted malts. Taste is a nicely roasted malty taste. Lite chalk ash, lite bitter chocolate, not very oatmeal but still good. Body is on the lighter side for an oatmeal stout. But very creamy and smooth. The low alcohol content is enjoyable.Overall: Nice low alcohol stout
Bottled. Courtesy of jaghana. Huge amounts of apples in the nose. Roasted malt throughout. Tasty, quite pleasant but far from being great.
Bottle 341 ml. Pours black with a tan head. Oatmeal, dark chocolate, licorice and coffee in aroma. Bitter chocolate, roasted malts and salty licorice in flavor.

355ml bottle. So damn good... Approaches stout perfection -- and in deceptively simple packaging. The tendency is to undersell anything thats available in a six-pack. Dont make that mistake. This ale is premium, decadent deliciousness.
Pours out like motor oil with a pillowy head.  Sweet aromas of toast, oats and a slight buttery finish.  Flavors of toast,  coffee and earth.  A slightly bitter finish,

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2013 Larôme du café, du chocolat, et un peu davoine torréfiée. Légèrement amer avec un goût initiale du café et chocolat avec une finition légèrement amer. La palate (pour 5% abv) épais donne plus de temps pour explorer les notes subtile torréfiée.

This has an awesome aroma! Very nutty with hints of coffee and chocolate cake. Not too impressed with the palate though  a bit lighter than I was expecting, but not bad. The taste is very smokey and malty. Good stout!

Pours an opaque black with tan head with one finger height and moderate lacing. Boozy and dark chocolate nose with coffee and oatmeal flavors presenting later in the tasting. hint of dark fruit. Mild taste of british hops. Initially seems tat it will be sweet, but actually turns moderately bitter.  Medium body with moderate carbonation. This would be good under nitro tap. Thin mouthfeel.  Finish is long with tobacco and espresso.  This is pretty good, although I am surprised at the acclaim. I may had to try this in Canada to get a fresher sample. 

Addendum: on review of other ratings, I do agree with the licorice flavor

Pours a not entirely black dark charcoal brown into snifter, with a nice off-biege head not even a fingernail in length. Nosed straightaway liquorice, Dutched chocolate, coffee dregs, brown sugar and some roast. A little too sweet to give it any higher of a score in its aroma than a 6, unfortunately. Mmm, thats good. Starts bittersweet with notes of brownie mix, hops, cinnamon and liquorice. By swallow Im getting lactose, coffee, booze and dark fruits, especially plums. Ends with soured milk, hops and soil. A little unimpresssed with its aftertaste, but its genuinely a solid a Stout.

Pours dark black/brown with light brown head. Aroma of roastiness and wet dog. A dryer taste than I like, with only light hints of coffee or chocolate. Also some fruity flavor, which is a little weird. Highly carbonated for a stout, and seems to be closer to a porter on the mouthfeel. Not bad, but nowhere near my favorite for this style. A bit disappointed.

Jet black pour one finger creamy head high carbonation well hidden alcohol notes of espresso dark chocolate this is a very simple but elegant little stout

Rich dark brown/black color; Medium to heavy slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, coffee, & chocolate; Flavor of roasted/burnt malt, coffee, hops, oats, and dark chocolate; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Great session stout.
No notes for me. First time rating. Just know that this is one super delicious - good for my tummy - beer!!

A: Snifter pour: deep dark onyx with a lively brown cap. Retention is excellent.

S: Molasses, toffee, caramel, dark fruits like fig. Light sweetness is apparent as well

T: Oh boy, real mellow. Light cocoa, slight lactose, dark berries and raisin. Molasses and toffee follow chocolate and coffee. Real big, nice an simple

MF/O: Super viscous, super smooth, creamy, and velvety. The best feel to a beer that Ive ever experienced. By far.

Had a nitrogen pulled pint of this last night.  Extremely creamy head with great mouth feel.  Strong coffee notes and excellent balance, not too bitter but not overwhelmingly sweet.  If you can get this on tap, highly recommended.

On tap at St Augustines. Pours black with fine medium head. Light roasted malt aroma with hints of chocolate. Very smooth. Full mouth feel but still light and creamy. Flavors of roasted (not burnt) malts and light milk chocolate. Slightly sweet.

11.5oz bottle. Good thin brown head. Black color. Bubbles on the side of the glass. Some dots of lace. Thin watery body. Light crisp carbonation. Good creaminess, though. very nice oaty aroma, milk chocolate, light roast. Nice moderate sweet taste. Very light espresso note. Nicely done, tasty, but I think I prefer the classic USA-style. A double version of this might be interesting, if it wasnt made too sweet.

Keg at the Craft Beer Market, Calgary. It pours jet black, with a thick, light tan head. The nose is roasted malt, charcoal, coffee and cocoa powder. The taste is roasted malt, rich coffee, charred wood, cocoa powder, subtle acidity, creaminess and light treacle, with a smooth, dry finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Well made, great balance and flavour. Drinks all to easily....

Black pour decent sized tan/beige head ... aroma of toasted almonds, light lactose, roasted malts, and caramel malts .... taste is of roasted and caramel malts, toffee, chocolate, light lactose and toasted almonds ... mouthfeel is thin .... finises dry with a light bitter bite ... complex and tasty for an oatmeal stout bordering a sweet stout

Black pour with a light tan, thick head. Aroma is roasted malt, not strong. Flavor is primarily about the roasted malt component, which dominates. A strong hop bitterness too. Not bad, but too simple, too heavy on the roasted aspect for my taste.

Received in a pint glass from a nitro tap. Nice creamy head with cascade as expected.Dark brown almost black once settled. Not much aroma through the foam. The tase is mostly malt and chocolate with a little smokiness. Mouthfeel is medium to light. not as exciting as I expected. A good Oatmeal Stout thats easy to drink

Black pour with a fluffy tan head that laces down the glass. Aroma of rich roasted malts, creamy oats with lighter notes of coffee and subtle tart berry. Roasted malts throughout the flavor with oats, and slight lactic sourness. Pretty tasty and easy drinking stout.
UPDATED: OCT 4, 2012 (bottle). Pours a dark brown with tan head. Aroma of roasted malt. The flavor is somewhat watery with well roasted malt. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle to snifter. Looks good; pitch black with tan head. Smells malty. Tastes like it smells with good balance and a pleasant mouthfeel. A great example of the style.

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co., and nitro pushed to a logo-ed pint glass with a black/brown color, a persistent, bubbles & cream, brownish tan head, and clingy waves & spray as lacing. Initially sensitive to a hint of tartness, with the remaining aroma notes as dry and roasted coffee, some graininess, and touches of caramel and char. Continued dry roastiness in the flavor, with a thin body, almost watery texture, soft effervescence, and light silkiness to the mouthfeel. Reasonably sessionable if not too offended by the thin and tart.
170217. Tap at brouwers, seattle. Pours black with a long light brown head that lasts. Aroms creamy roasted malts, coffee, oats. Smooth long finish. Not Bad.

341 ml bottle. Finland.
Black colour with small to average size tan head.
Aroma is roasted malt, bitterish (berry) hops, chocolate and mild buttery elements. 
Flavour is roasted malt, sweetness, chocolate, mild coffee notes, butter and balancing hops. Smooth and rich. Nice Stout.

Rating #2200 ! Bottle 341ml, a very dark beer with huge brown head. Nose is roasted, coffee like with dark chocolate notes. Aroma is very creamy on dark chocolate and roasted notes, licorice at the finish with light metallic touch. Body is smooth and very enjoyable, light soy sauce notes.

11.5oz bottle poured into an English pint. Pours black with about a finger of dark tan head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate along with some dark fruits. Taste is light bitter. Coffee and chocolate with dark fruits.  Light bodied with a pretty thin and watery texture. Flat carbonation but a decently long finish. Overall, not bad. I wouldnt seek it out but Ill enjoy this one.

Thanks weihenweizen! Tasted from 11.5oz bottle into nucleated pint glass. It poured a thick, opaque, motor oil dark brown color with brown foam as well, long-lasting with sticky lace. Excellent protein from oatmeal and unmalted barley. Aromas of cranberry, red grape skins and plum from the roasted grain and ale yeast esters, molasses, caramelized malt, dark toast, hints of chocolate and coffee, really roasty. Same flavors as aromas but breadier, with a smooth, balanced bitterness from earthy hops, burnt barley, and smooth alcohol. Combined with the fruitiness, it reminded me of an aged port or plum-wine. Began with a rich malt sweetness but it finished dry. Creamy and chewy mouthfeel. A bit oxidized with a slight sourness, somehow chalky and acidic at the same time. Medium body and carbonation.This bottle may have been old, but it wasnt a problem for this style. Lingering fruity, bittersweet aftertaste. A refined French-Canadian, wine-like interpretation of English stout. Well-crafted, balanced, and utterly delicious.
Black as night. Savory, smoky nose. Full bodied, yet approachable with smoke, espresso bean and some plummy black fruit. Lively mouthfeel and a dry finish. Excellent!

Most prolly the best oatmeal stout I tried along with the Corriveau from Bilboquet. Really enjoyable and easily drinkable. That cereal and roasty creamy taste is just wonderful. Well balanced. Enough said.
Draft at railroad. Pours black with a finger of tan head. aroma reminds me of a coffee plus guinness. The taste is light and very coffee full on the finish. Really good light stout.

Pours black with lasting tan head and lace. Aroma is coffee, dark chocolate, black licorice, vanilla, roast malts. Taste coffee, bitter chocolate, black licorice, roast malts. Full body, somewhat sticky with coffee finish.

11.5oz bottle - pours black with brown head.  Nose is coffee, dark chocolate and oatmeal.  Flavor adds roastiness and some hops.  Taste is sweet at first but then very bitter.  Full body but yet easy to drink.  Watery to sticky texture.  Not as malty as I would expect.
Bière très noire. Arôme davoine grillée, de café, de chocolat. Goût assez prononcé de café. Excellente.
Oh yeah. This is amazing. Thick and awesome. Great notes of coffee and chocolate. I cant even describe it I like it that much.

Best local stout in the Montreal area. 

Great taste from a beer that has the appearance of a black hole!
Totally satisfying.  Order it whenever I can. Top notch.  Great drinker when you want to have a few.

Mocha coloured head over a midnight black body. Roasted coffee and cocoa aromas. Flavours have roastiness in to them. lots of coffee and cocoa and the tiniest bit of funk on the end. Smooth and creamy with a medium to full body.

11.5oz bottle.  Pours a deep black color with a two finger light brown head, that had plenty of lacing and good retention.   Aroma is toasted oats, sweet chocolate, and rich coffee.   Big dark malt flavors, chocolate, coffee, vanilla and a touch of wood. Extremely smooth. Creamy and slightly sweet.  The finish is bitter and dry, with charcoal notes.  Perfectly balanced.

341 ml bottle.  Pours almost black with a nice tan head.  Aroma of roast, chocolate, coffee, and molasses.  Taste is roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, and molasses.  Somewhat bitter aftertaste.  Very nice.

On tap @ Barque Toronto.  Poured like black molasses with a huge creamy mocha colored head.  Aroma was rich malts and smoke.  Taste was roasty, coffee, oats, and semi-sweet chocolate.  Full creamy mouthfeel with a mildly bitter, astringent finish.  Fantastic stout.

Pitch black pour with creamy head that hangs on throughout. Smells are complex.. Chocolate, oats, sweet. Smooth on the palatte like a milkshake. Taste is two tone. Roasted chocolate and then earthy and creamy.

Very dark in color with a tasty looking frothy delicioius head. Aromas of big roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, burnt malts. Wow, the flavors are of roasted malts, dark chocolate, light smoke, light wood, and some more wow. Velvet on the palate, smooth, light roasted malt aftertaste, slightly bitter. Good good stuff. Would buy again.

Pours a jet black with a fluffy light brown head that lingers. Nose is dry & earthy. Taste is sweet, dry, and oaty. A solid brew indeed. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A strong showing in the oatmeal stout department; malty with strong tones of dark roasting of the oats and barley.

Hopping is stronger than in other comparable oatmeal stouts, with a more pronounced bitter, astringent finish. 

If youre used to Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout, youll find this beer a little more hoppy and bitter, overall, but the comparisons are strong. Delicious!

I use this drink as an archetype with which to rate other stouts. It deserves it. Is there any other beer so beautiful? Perfectly balanced with the roast and hops. As complex as a good imperial stout, just bursting with the flavour I want from an oatmeal stout. Aromas are coffee and chuclate, aftertaste makes you swallow air to belch more. Smooth smooth smooth.

2 finger dirty brown head with some bubles in it. Jet black with mabye  a tad little brown at bottom near light. some carbination but not easy to see it.  Smell is of roasted peanuts,roasted coffee & chocolate. Taste is a little water,a little sour on the left side for a while,a little bittier tingle on tounge,and what i smell i also taste,roasted nuts,roasted coffee & chocolate. stout & dark beer fan but I can say i had better stouts. Heavy bodied good but i dont think as good as others make claim to but to each there own cheers.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2012 341ml bottle. Pours a gorgeous 3/4" thick mocha head. Becomes a playful lace in short order. Aroma is wonderful fudge, nuts and coffee. Body is dark black-chestnut (Lovibond 39/40). Tastes like heaven. I cant do any better than the description... Its velvety perfection. Never had a better beer, let alone a better stout. Not too sweet either!

St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout is probably the best six pack widely available in Toronto area LCBOs. Beer is black in colour with a delicious foamy head. Very rich and complex in flavours, in particular a strong smokey mocha flavour.
Pours black...aroma of some fruit and chocolate...slight bitter aftertaste...good
Pours dark, little head. Tastes light, a little bitter after bite. Decent oatmeal stout

This is a professional feeling beer.  Looks good.  Pours good.  Smart label.  Theres something in the middle of the drink that seems lacking, and its a little too bitter of an aftertaste.  But everything else from pour to sniff to swallow gets my attention for a stout.  Very good.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2012 April 21 2012. 341ml bottle pours solid black with 2-3 inch tan fluffy head. Aroma of strong coffee and sweet chocolate. Taste like black coffee with hints of oats. Chocolate is more of a dark bitter kind than sweet milk. Sweet at first but quickly turns to bitterness of a Tim hortons black coffee and the oatmeal gives it weight both on the tongue and stomach. Silky palate with strong bitter lingering. I love my black timmys and I love this beer. Only downfall: it is a very heavy beer, drinks like a meal.

Pours dark brown in color with an off-white head.  Roasted malt with a touch of cocoa and some coffee, maybe a little bit of smoke, too.  The flavor is somewhat smokey as well with quite a bit of roasted malt and coffee.  Just a little bit of cocoa/chocolate sweetness.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Rotems place. Thanks DSG. Pours black with a brown head and a sweet chocolate liquor aroma, with some plum as well. Tastes sweet, then bitter and alcoholic, but nice altogether. No carbonation, heavy body and sweet finish.

Pours pitch black with a tan head.  Aroma contains almond, licorice, chocolate, toffee.  Chocolate, coffee and toffee dominate the taste.  Pretty smooth on the tongue.  Coffee aftertaste lasts a long time.  Enjoyable, but not my first pick.

Pours black with a thick tan head. Good lacing. Aromas of molasses, vanilla, roasted almonds. Smooth body with low carbonation. Flavours replicating the nose with some coffee. Medium bitterness on the finish. Nice.

Bottle via trade with Weihenheizen. Thanks! Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Appearance is a dark, dark brown, nearly black with tan head of foam that dissipates somewhat quickly. Aroma is super roasty with loads of coffee beans and dark chocolate. Nearly a hint of licorice. Taste is mildly bitter, much like a double shot of espresso, tobacco-esque. Quite a complex beer on the tongue. Super dark chocolate also comes to mind, but more so in the finish. Mildly drying in the finish with a lingering coffee taste remaining on the tongue long after the finish. This beer is quite conducive to a sipping occasion. If a person has the chance to pick a few or more of these up, please do so. You will not regret that decision. Thanks a ton, David!

Bottle. Dark brown color with a small light brown head. Roasted malt in the aroma with notes of coffee and chocolate. Flavour is slightly sweet, roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and some bitterness. Smooth, medium-bodied. Dry and bitter aftertaste.

Dark brown pretty much just a black hole of color complete with a tall brown crown floating on top. Smells like a cold cup of coffee sitting here in front of me, campfire ash after a rain storm, mild sour, deep rich bakers chocolate, all of it smells good. Tastes like happiness. Cold coffee, dark chocolate, a blueberry like sweetness, tiny tiny elements of cinnomen. Man is this drinkable. Cold black coffee cant be said enough. Finish is sweet but then a lingering bitterness takes over. Cant beleave it took me this many years to give this a review.
On draft pour.  Black color with a light head.  Licorice, and chocolate.  Nice drinkable oatmeal stout.

Bottled. Roasty slightly smokey nose with some hints of chocolate. Pale brown head. Dark brownish black colour. Malty roasty and chocolatey taste with some licorice. At the end hoppy bitterness. Good fullfilled dry stout.

On tap at Elizabeth Station: Inky black. Roasty, rich and tasty. Wonderful aromas of coffee and roast. Milky, caramelly sweetness is balanced well by a slight lactic sourness, a bold roastiness, and a healthy bitterness. Dryish aftertaste also cleaves off some sweetness. Pleasant and flavorful stout.

Bottle 341 ml [2011]. Appearance: Pours black with a nice big brown lasting head. Aroma: Smoked, roasted coffee, sweet. Taste: Roasted coffee, raisin, smoked. Overall: Nice stout, but the body is thin.
Extremely dark with a dark caramel head. Great stout flavor: sweet/espresso/chocolate with a nice finish.  A top notch beer. Definitely going back for more.

Black as night with a creamy, caramel colored head.  Not a speck of light comes through the glass.  Odor of malt and coffee, but less intense than some coffee scented brews.  Head fades to lace in short order.  Rush of roasted malt on the tongue followed by coffee and a hint of chocolate.  Warms the palate and leaves that wonderful roasted taste lingering.  One of the very best in Canada, everyone should have a chance to try it at least once.

Pours a brownish black with a frothy cappuccino head. Aroma is hops, resin, and dough. Taste is roasty malts, smoke, and chocolate. Smoothness of palate is coupled with moderate carbonation. Pretty average, for a stout and an oatmeal stout.
Arome de café moka. Robe noire opaque surmonté dun collet brun pâle. Tout comme larome, goût de moka. Une carbonatation légère. Voila une stout remarquable.

Bottle 341ml.
Pours black, withmassive brown, creamy head. Good lacing. Aroma is of sugar, roasted matl, coffee and oat. Taste is of roasted malt, oats and coffee. Nicely balanced, but a bit watery. A very good stout.

5.0% 330ml bottle
Pours a beautiful thick amazing coffee cream tight head which falls in on itself to a standstill of a finger width. Aroma is roasty toasty. Black in appearance, even with a flashlight behind it. Perfect carbonation. Lacing clings unbelievably. I could chew on this beer. dry finish. One of, if not my favorite beers.

bottle courtesy of coldbrewky pours a jet black hue with tan on the edges, capped by a tan head with great retention. hint of roast in the nose. Roast, light bittering chocolate, toffee all add to a complex taste. Mouth is light and super creamy. Amazing.

35cl bottle poured into a Trappiste chalice. Next time Ill use a pint glass. Minimal head fully diminished, but a beautiful caramel/tan, like creme on espresso. Body is dark as night. Black licorice aroma. Oats, chocolate, espresso caramel flavours. Fully bodied palate. Creamier the longer it goes. Not quite as smooth as Guinness. Lively carbo. Medium dry finish. A real gem. Not always bad to have a lower alcohol offering in a beer.
Bottle - Murky black with dark tan head.  Low carbonation.  Full bodied.  Smooth. Roasted malts. Smoky.  Bitter finish.

Thick viscous black body with a red underpinning and an espresso cream head that settles into a thin layer. The aroma is oil thick with some sooty hints. Again, the body is soot oil and black patent. Exceptionally deep roastiness across a medium body with some soap ash that sticks to the back of the throat.
Decent beer. Black color, roasted malts, a bit of smokiness. Oat flavor is very mild, some chocolate and coffee, a touch on the bitter side.
Bottle.  Pours black with a tan head.  Nice roasted malt, chocolate, coffee.  Silky texture.  Good flavor.  Well done.

Yet another beer from the Blue Mountain Construction gods.  Nose of licorice and dark malt.  Lively luxurious head leaves behind thick quaff rings interconnected with gentle lacing. Body is just a big as it needs to be without muscling you about.  Long lasting body eases into identical long lasting finish.  Some thin black patent appears and signals the end....or the start of a new mouthful...  Yes this could be dangerous if I had more than three.
Nice, simple stout. Large head that diminishes quickly, very dark. Thin nose and a straightforward, but quite tasty flavour with a nice lingering, smoky aftertaste.

Pours black with a frothy tan head, There lots going on here aroma wise, notes of rich bitter chocolate and roasted cereals dominate. the aroma is incredible, i gave it a 10 for whats it worth. Its flavour makes this beer an excellent after dinner or perhaps a dessert beer. I notice some hops and alcohol on the palate but the roasty toasty malts rule here and this beer finishes nice and dry with enough pleasant aftertaste to invite the next sip.

The worlds best conventional ABV-level stout. Sure why not? It is a sinister oily brown t0 black. Very viscous with much lacing. Aroma of dark roast coffee but also sweet like buttery chocolate chip cookies. Rich chocolate malt flavor with hints of vanilla and toffee. Thick texture thats not overwhelmingly heavy. Everything a standard stout should be, and nothing it shouldnt.

Served on nitro-tap at Als of Hampden into a nonic pint.

A - Pours deep black with a thick, creamy, one finger light tan head, dissipating down to a light creamy film, leaving thick rings of lacing down the entire glass.

S - Nice balance of dark roasted graham cracker malts and rich coffee. A touch of hops come thru as it warms up a bit. Nothing over the top here, just a solid oatmeal stout.

T - Lots of dark roasted malt up front giving way slowly to a mix of dark roasted coffee and some faint bittersweet chocolate. Finish has a good amount of dark roasted malt, but the watery feel that develops once it warms up doesnt help this one much. I still liked it tho, solid stuff.

M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. A bit watery toward the end of the glass. Finish has some dark roast that lingers for a short period of time.

D - Pretty high. I liked this one on the brand new nitro faucet as it poured much better than the old one. Pretty good balance but the watery feel toward the end brought this one down a notch or two. Good stuff none the less.

341 ml, bottled. Pours black with a mocha head. Aroma: Licorice, soy, coffee, roasted malt. Taste: Mild sweetness, discernable bitterness. Roasted flavours, coffee. Palate: Medium-full body, pleasant carbonation. Nice stout.
UPDATED: JAN 12, 2012 Roasted malt aroma. Dark color with a small white head. Sweet light beginning with a roasted and slightly chalky finish.

Black with a thick tan head. Aromas of molasses, chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Medium creamy body. Very smooth. Smoky dark malt and molasses. Very clean finish that is slightly salty. Good balanced stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

At a tasting in "Sar Hamashkaot" in Ramat Gan, thanks Oren, bottle, pours very dark brown color almost without head, toffee, chocolate and smoky aroma, smoky, bonfire and charred wood taste, medium body, flows, overall a complex and rich beer with exquisite taste.

Bottled. Black beer with a thin creamy head. Sweetish, bready malt aroma with coffeyish notes. Some prunes. Dry malt body with good toasted bread note, a hint of caramel. Slightly ashy finish with coffee roastedness. Surprisingly bitter finish, long lasting sourish roast. Soft, velvety texture, nice dry finish. Well balanced beer.
Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Taste surprisingly bitter all the way through. Burnt coffee flavor.
Bottle - pours black with a brown head. Has a roasty malt aroma and flavor to it. Has a thin and smooth mouthfeel.

Draught at Cest What. Pours black with a creamy tan head. Smells faint of oatmeal and malt. Tastes a medium bitter with a medium sweetness. Full bodied. Creamy texture. Soft carbonation. Finishes bitter. Very pleasant, but not something Id go looking for.
UPDATED: DEC 31, 2011 #1054 bottle; Nose is roasted, velvet malt, walnut, earth, feel is watery, carb is medium, taste is decent, quite sharp malt, leather, earth, later some mediumweak cough syrup

Bière noire au col couleur mocha, dont la mousse est généreuse et persistante. Nez de chocolat, davoine et de pâte à pain. Goût davoine, de chocolat noir, de café noir, laissant une belle et agréable amertume en arrière-goût. Vraiment un beau produit. (125-031211 / MA-301113)
Excellent.  Pours completely dark with frothy brown-ish head.  Aroma of malt and chocolate.  Delicious
Black with a dark brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, chocolate and moderate butter. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 221211
Bottle. Black with big light brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, butter and chocolate. Flavour is roasted malts, medium sweet, chocolate, little coffee, liquorice, caramel, hops  and a little bitter.
Bottle. Huge creamy head with excellent duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, butter, caramel, licorice, coffee, chocolate and hops.
So far as stouts go, this is a nice beer. Creamy head, nice cascade, yeasty aroma. It ranks behind the Peche in terms of my personal preference.

DRAFT at Hopleaf in Chicago.  Pours dark with tannish head....frankly, a little disappointed.  Probably drawn way too cold....flavors coming thru better by the time I finished it off, despite trying to warm it...definite hints of expresso and chocolate, but much less than Id expected.  Actually thought it was a Guinness for first few sips...good but not great to me.

341 ml bottle.
Originally rated on 20110615. (7+4+8+3+15)
Pours pitch black colour with thick and lasting head. First thing on the nose is a very dry, ashy chocolaty aroma, dry coffee also. Coffee and ash dry chocolate is strong on the flavour also. Resembles Guinness Extra Export Stout in some ways. As the beer warms up a bit, even more mocha-like chocolate and roasted malts emerge. Palate is dry and a bit sourish bitter. Surprisingly full-bodied for such low abv. NIce and balanced brew.
4325
Absolutely perfect for a cold winter evening.  My personal gold standard for oatmeal stouts.

opaque black with a creamy tan head: full but not thick body, with medium-high carbonation.

aroma: strong grain-husky minerality, dark sweet malt, chocolate malt, some silage, leafy hops, and a bit of alcohol esters.

taste: lots of astringent black malt or dark-roasted barley with some husky tannins, notes of cola and chocolate.

not really detecting the oats- no silky texture or nutty flavor.
Pours black with dark brown head.  Aroma of lightly roasted grains, some sweetness.  Rich malt taste, not too thick in the mouth, finishes a little bitter.

on draft, pours very dark with tan head that lasted for a bit and the lacing in the glass stayed there. the first aroma was of caramel  and roasted malts. the taste was of caramel and roasted malts, for me this is a medium to light bodied beer i thought it would be chewier, i got light oats from this...the warmer it got the thinner it got and that roastiness turned to a sweeter flavor.

bottle from local Iga A: roasty, chocolaty, some caramel. App: pitch black beige head nice lacing. T/p: full body finish is bitter and long. Med Carbonation. Pleasant texture from the oatmeal. O: Excellent..a standard.

Pitch black, frothy mocha head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and dark roasted malts. Tastes the same. Silky, solid and chewy. Light bitter finish.
NFL (Not for Lagerboys)

Superbe apparence; noir opaque avec une mousse onctueuse, chocolaté et persistante.  Une odeur de chocolat amer délicieuse mais vite atténué, probablement par la mousse épaisse.  Très soyeuse en bouche, chocolat noir au goût et qui persiste en arrière goût.  Un tout petit peu acide.  Une des meilleures stout.

from tap at Ottawa Food and Wine Show. St. Ambroise, still to make my mind up about these guys. Some of their offerings are distinctly sub par however the Oatmeal Stout is the complete opposite and certainly punches wel above, what i percieve to be, their weight. Black, chocolate brown colour with an appealing tan coloured head. Lovely nutty malt on the nose which are present on the tongue too along with deep espresso and rich dark chocolate flavours. A satisfying mouthful

From a bottle, poured into an official glass. Pitch black and opaque with a thick brownish head, very good retention. Tastes mostly roasted, dark chocolatey and somewhat like cereal on the finish (oatmeal, I guess?). Very thick body, quite delicious. Warms one up quite well on cold Quebec nights. An almost flawless classic.

Bottle 33 cl, Alko Arkadia. Pours pitch black with a great creamy brown head leaving nice lacing. Aroma is malty, roasted, earthy and coffee. Flavor is roasted, ashy, coffee, chocolate, acidy, bitter and a bit fruity. Finishes acidy, bitter and malty.

Pours a deep, muddy black with a light brown-sugar head.  Aroma is sweet and malty, with hints of salt, licorice, and chocolate.  Full-bodied with an upfront sweet malt, subtle coffee, and a subtle savory finish.  Soft and smooth.
11.5 oz bottle.  Pours a black with a tan head.  Sweet molasses, cocoa and vanilla aroma, butterscotch.  Flavor is very ashen, molasses, a little cocoa and butterscotch again.  Not bad at all.
awesome aroma. . very good stout well balanced with the sweetness. have had this twice now, the second time was pretty bad.. probably a bad bottle. (rating the first one obviously)

34,1 cl bottle @ OHaras Freehouse, Tampere. Rated on 15.06.2011
Aroma has roasted malt and some coffee with hints of saltish licorice. Feels like a foreign stout actually. Flavour is rather dry with roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Feels a bit like Guinness Draught. Very good and rather rich for a 5% ABV stout.
Smells like honeyed breakfast cereal and leaves off tasting like a soft bitter stout. Excellent body and full package.

6-pack from the Beer Store.  This is a big smokey stout.  Pours black with a brown head.  Aroma and taste of chocolate and coffee are present, with a nice smokiness, and a bitter finish.  One of my favourite stouts.

My first review, I will start with one of the better beers, on tap at Tyler"s Apex, pour was to cold, let sit, nice black color. nice chocolate and malt taste with slight oatmeal taste, flavor is better as it warms, drinks very smooth can have more than one or two of these with the alcohol percentage being low.
Coffee, chocolate, toasty, and with a hint of smoke, this stout packs a wallop. And fair enough, because its to-die-for. This is a mainstay of my fridge.

341ml bottle from Alko. Poured black with a creamy, brown head. Aroma has roasted malt, dark chocolate and strong coffee. Flavor is quite similar. Looong coffee taste in finish. Well made stout, but some off notes in the aroma lowers my rating a couple of points. Could rate again later.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2011 Refrigerated bottle complements of pushkinwow through trade poured into a glass.  Pours coal black with big medium brown head.  Good small bubble lacing, medium/thick smooth body, and sticky texture.  Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, and some bitterness in the finish.
One of the greatest stout in the world. The oatmeal gives an incredible creamy sensation. Perfectly balance.

Bottle courtesy of Strykzone. Poured a very  black color with a very robust  dark tan head and sticky lacing rings. Nose of roasted malts with chocolate, coffee, and vanilla.  Medium to full body and a slick creamy palate.  Flavor is strong with coffee leading  the way but there is some hops there too. Bitter finish. Excellent.

Bottle- Pours a virtual black color with a creamy tan head that fades very slowly to nice fine lacing. Aroma is a mixture of chocolate, coffee and a dash of spice. Has a good bittersweet flavor up front with a subtle bitterness though toa nice dry finish. Medium body, creamy smooth with and excellent balance. Has a distinct character that makes it stand out without overpowering. Outstanding stout, spot-on. Perfect was to end the day.

deep brown, brown edges with decent tan head, limited lacing... licorice, coffee, chocolate, lightly sour.. flavor matches, decent, lightly anise, nice creamy body the oatmeal plays nicely, a little sweet, nice beer...
best oatmeal stout Ive had.  Excellent flavor balance in terms of both sweet/bitter and malt/hops/oatmeal.  Highly recommended.

Bottle. Very dark brown  almost black, average and diminishing dark brown head. Moderate to malty   oaty and sweetish aroma, coffee and some roasted malt, faint salty licorice. Body is medium, malty  lightly oaty and sweetish flavor, lots of coffee and some roasted malt and faint licorice. Finish is average, malty  some oat and sweetish, lots of coffee and some roasted malt. Sweetish (oatmeal)stout with lots of coffee.

Bottle. Pours a dark, black coffee color with a gorgeous, large, dark latte head. Aroma is roasted oats, chocolate, tones of coffee and hints of liquorice. Taste is roasted oats and malts, some chocolate, tones of coffee and (unfortunately) soy sauce. Dry aftertaste with cooca and chocolate. Palate is medium.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2014 Bottle. Very black color, with medium head. Herb and roasted grain aroma and taste. Fine hop bitterness to finish.

My favorite stout! Tons of roast flavor, unbeatable body for a 5% ABV brew...and completely black color.
This is a beautiful beer. Maybe my favorite widely available beer in Canada! Big black ale with piles of initial coffee and chocolate aromas. Medium thick in the mouth. Great stuff.

12 oz bottle.  Simply put......not good.  Given this is considered a top stout I would like to give it another shot on a fairly fresh palate.  Otherwise it was too soy saucy on the nose and the taste.

Appearance: Very dark brown, almost black. Nice tan head.
Aroma: Dark fruit and dark malt.
Taste: Dark malt, coffee, Not bad.
Info: 341ml bottle, 14/7-2011

Midnight black pour with a tight, dark tan head. Looks much bigger than the abv suggests. Deep and rich aromas of tar, dark fruits (esp raisins), vanilla, espresso and dark chocolate. Really full and expressive. Flavour is a superb balance of raisins, chocolate, vanilla lactose sweetness and an assertive, lingering roastiness. Great weight on the palate. Only complaint is that the dark fruit character and heavy roast finish begin to dominate some of the more subtle nuances. Overall an amazing beer.

341ml Bottle. Dark black void with a full creamy tan head. Aromas of chocolate and coffee. Feels creamy in the mouth with chocolate and slight coffee coming through. Finishes incredibly smooth with an aftertaste that makes me want more. I love this beer!
341ml bottle. Colour was black as night. Taste was very good. Body was not watery, as stouts can be.

Appearance:  black, half-finger tan head shrinking slowly to a thick collar, some lace.  Aroma: chocolate, coffee, freshly rolled oats.   Taste: chocolate covered coffee beans, fresh-baked oatmeal cookies, notes of vanilla and cream.  Finish: long, smooth, mellow, and dry (although not as brutally talc-dry as some heavy-handed takes on the style) with a hint of sour tang coming out once it warms to near room temp.   Notes: 	Very fine oatmeal stout.  A great example of a great style.

Had this on draught. Poured jet black with about an inch and a half of head. Beautiful sweet chocolate/coffee smell. Very smooth almost creamy mouthfeel. Chocolate and coffee flavours that get better the warmer the beer gets. Beautiful beer, quite possibly my favourite stout ot there there
Best Oatmeal stout ive had to date. Nice smooth texture and a froathy head. Very nice malting and sugars. Smooth.

Not easy to get hold of, I have found this online at Slowbeer and at the international beer shop.

My Favourite beer at the moment, however not session beer (still able to have 2-3 to start off a session) and one to drink to enjoy. Black chocolate is prominent with a perfect amount of coffee flavour. Cold sensation when running down the throat.
Drought at Zaphod Beeblebrox, Ottawa. Dark brown with creamy amber-white head, coffee beans-cocoa flavor, mild carbonation, slightly sour taste, medium finish. A nice one.

This is one of my fav styles of beer. Dark black pour that was thick and silky. Soft roasty aroma with some cookie and chocolate. Taste is the same - chocolate, cookie like, super super smooth. Love it!

341ml bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki

Pours black with a small brown head. Aroma has hints of roasted malt, ash and smoke. Taste is quite malty with notes of fruitness and roasted bitterness. Carbonated, medium bodied.

341 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Pikkulintu, Helsinki.
Pours a black, slightly transparent colour with a white, lacy head. Aroma of sweet fruits, caramel, roasted malts and some hay. Flavour of grassy hops, roasted malts, caramel, fruits and smoke. Medium bodied with a slick mouthfeel and a roasty finish with some coffee. Good and tasty.

St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout is the real deal.  On tap at Longroom and Eagle in Chicago.  Pours dark with a medium tan head.  Taste is dark chocolae with an espresso finish.  Smooth and creamy on the palate.  Softer texture than other oatmeals Ive had.  This one is both the sizzle and the steak.  Excellent.

12 oz. bottle. Pours black as a moonless midnight. With a thick, creamy mocha head that died down after about 2 minutes. Light lace. Aroma of sweet and dark malts with notes of caramel and licorice. Toasted oats, malt and nice chocolate. The oatmeal gives it a very nice body with the soft carbonation, creates a creamy yet sticky mouthfeel. This finish gives you a dry ash feeling. Well balanced between sweet and bitter dry coffee. Has complexity in here. And It makes me want more. High drinkability. well done!
I love this beer, its a go to Stout - if you havent tried it you are failing yourself.
Bottle; black with medium light brown head; aroma-coffee, sour milk, roasty; taste- light sweetness, medium bitterness, salty, some sourness.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2011 Très savoureuse pour 5%. En bouche, elle est tout simplement onctueuse et riche. Très facile à trouver, pas cher et surprenante à chaque gorgée. De loin supérieur en fût, un classique montréalais.

Poured from a bottle.  black with a large brown head.  Nose is roast, some chocolate and yeasty esters.  Taste is nearly tart and dry with notes of roast.  Moderately medium light bodied.  Not really sure why its a 100/100

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2012 Élégante bière noire coiffée dun volumineux col chamoix produisant une belle dentelle.  Des arômes profonds de caramel, de café et davoine grillée.  Amertume complexe et multidimensionnelle.  De corps généreux, onctueux, une belle effervescence douce et une longue finale amère et aromatique.

Bottle from GT - thanks!  Thick, pock marked head of expresso-colored foam that laces it way down the glass.  Aroma is heavy on roasted malt and oat with a backbone of sweetish malt and bitter chocolate.  Flavor is roasted malt up front, a strong oat character, bitter chocolate, light expresso, and a tinge of sweet malt into the finish.  Light and easy feel in the mouth.  Solid and enjoyable low ABV stout.

Single bottle purchased from a Co-op Liqour store in Calgary, AB on 04/13/2011. Colour: Black with dark tan medium head. Nose: tar, oysters, baking rye bread, hint of root beer. Taste: Light sweet, light sour, medium bitter. Oatmeal with a dashing of brown sugar, some soft fruits appear but ever so shyly, mid to late storm of chalky meat char, roasted walnut and stale coffee. Gets a head nod.

Bouteille 341 mL - Noire opaque avec une énorme mousse moka. Arômes de chocolat et de café intense. Texture moelleuse pour un stout. Goût de café restant sur la langue avec une finale amère (et légèrement sûre??). Très très bon stout

A jet black pour with a frothy tan head and excellent lacing.  The aroma has dark chocolate, some coffee, and just a faint hint of hops.  The full body has a creamy texture with average carbonation.  The taste begins mildly sweet than changes over to a dry, roasted coffee finish.  Perhaps just a little too much coffee for my liking.

Bottle, thx tarheels. Pours black with a frothy tan head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, espresso. Taste is roasty, big chcolate, and drip coffee. Mouthfeel is creamy but finishes a bit watery. Overall, very good sessionable stout.

bottle, from trade with ???, Good aroma, sweet, roasty. Brownish black color, good head, minor lace. Sweet bitter flavor. Medium body, smooth creamy mouthfeel, swet bitter finish, Pretty good, another in a bunch of stuff Ive held onto too long, but it held up. Aroma best part, nice roast  & dairy mix.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text:
Pours black with tan head that lingers a while.  Aroma isnt strong from bottle.  Roast and oatmeal taste.  Smooth and light residual taste.
Good beer.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2011 Thx to robinvboyer for trade; huge fan of the oatmeal stout.  good coffe aroma.  had this cold  near room temp and at room temp - enjoyed best at near room temp.  slight hop in beginning; good amount of coffe flavor throughout; found that as this beer warmed it got thin and slightly sour at the end.

                                                                                                                                       

re-rate 11/2011 - year old bottle - dropped from 3.9 to 3.4  MUCH MUCH thinner than I remember nothing stood out; had at room temp

The beer pours black with one of the best heads Ive ever seen in my life. The head is tan, about 3 fingers with outstanding retention and lacing. The head stays at least 5 minutes and supremely coasts the glass. The head itself is so creamy its hard to describe. 

The aroma is nice and sweet with a bit of coffee. The taste is similar with great feel and drinkability.

Overall, this is an oustanding beer, wish it wasnt at the end of the night so I could have savored it more.
Maybe notes of Toffee.Definite Dark choco and coffee.Nice creaminess on tongue.Slight/Nice bitterness in end..

One of my favorite beers from one of my favorite styles for my 100th. 

St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout pours a deep and dark black with little light penetration. Two finger thick tan head developed with excellent retention. Plenty of lacing was deposited on the glass.

The aroma is classic stout. There are dark roasted malts with coffee and a touch of chocolate. The interesting characteristics of this particular stout include a bit of smoke in the nose.

The taste of this beer has many characteristics shared with Imperial Stouts but deliver them at 5%. Very impressive. The initial tasting is more subtle with coffee and roasted malts and a touch of dark chocolate. There is bit of nuttiness to it. The finish livens up and is a little more assertive. There is a nice bitterness in the finish.

The mouthfeel is creamy with moderate body. The carbonation is perfect for my liking and not too weak like many other stouts. 

This beer makes a great impression and tastes out of both its price and ABV league. This one is a winner and Ill be drinking it regularly.

Bottle/11.5oz - Pours very black in color with a small dark tan head and almost no carbonation.  Aroma is strong of espresso darkly roasted malts and some chocolate.  Flavor is strong of coffee with a nice touch of mocha in the middle.  Slightly sweet during the finish.  Medium bitter and quite smooth.  Palate is creamy and coats the tongue.  This is one of the better oatmeal stouts I have had in a while.  Very enjoyable...
UPDATED: APR 1, 2011 Smokey, oatey, roasty in aroma and taste. More smokey than the average stout. Great beer.

341ml bottle. Pours thick black brown head. Aroma is very strong, roasted coffee, chocolate, smoke. The taste is thick and complex, reflects the aroma but I also get a noticeable amount of smoked meat. Cest formidable!

Poured from a bottle, aged for a 9 months. Pitch black like sump oil, with an impressively smooth tan head that lasts a couple of minutes. Not a particularly powerful nose, but the expected coffee and stout malt is there, along with some vanilla and subtle rauchbier smoke. Delicate coffee and chocolate in the mouth, with a nutty finish. Creamy body. Compared to more robust oaties like Samuel Smiths the taste is very mild; sweeter and with less bitterness than I prefer. But you know what? Thisd make a great dessert beer.

Poured black with a thin tan head.  Great aroma of chocolate malts, oatmeal, and some caramel.  Taste has lots of chocolate malts with vanilla.  The finish has some wooden notes with oatmeal and coffee.  Some milky flavors as well, almost like a sweet stout.  Overall I like how the creaminess transitions into a bitter and flavorful finish.  Very good.
This one is tasty, the oatmeal in this beer adds a very smooth body to the beer, and blends everything very nicely together

On tap; pours very dark brown/black. Aroma of espresso and chocolate. Great very long lasting mocha colored head. Taste was similar to aroma, with good body. Overall a good beer ... just wish I tried separately from the other beers I tried it with side by side.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown, black in the glass, with a large, frothy 3-finger brown head.  The head recedes to a rocky covering, and leaves thick lacing.  The aromas are toffee, caramel, slight butterscotch, and cocoa/chocolate.  The flavor is cocoa and slight mocha, coffee, and lactose, with a bitter coffee and pine finish.  This is smooth; low carbonation and creamy, medium to full-bodied, with a dry finish.  Very good, well-balanced.  [603]

Pours jet black with a small tan head. Fades quickly and leaves some good lacing. Aromas of cocoa, coffee, wood and smoke. Taste is coffee and wood first up which gradually turns into a bitter cocoa finish. Smoke in there too. It lingers for ages ! Great beer

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2011 On tap today at a new pub and WOW did I forget how great of a beer this is on draft compared to the bottle. Dark black with a creamy tan head that leaves beautiful lacing all the way down the pint glass. Overall the beer is much smoother and creamier. more full bodied, less bitter and better balanced on tap when compared to the bottle. The roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and oats really shine through; it starts slightly bitter with some sweetness that quickly disappears, the finish is perfectly dry without overwhelming, full bodied, perfect balance of carbonation, and a finish that while relatively simple is still very well done. Highly recommend trying this if you see it somewhere on tap - but let it warm up. 

341ml Bottle: a great go to session beer. Pours light black with a copper hugh, light tan head and high carbonation. Aroma is roasted, smoke, molasses and barley. Very smooth taste, slight bitterness that continues on for a bit and then fades. Not overly complex but still very tasty.

Tasted on 2/9/11 from an 11.5oz bottle obtained in a trade.  Pours opaque almost black with an average tan head that slowly recedes to thin but even lace.  The nose is predominantly chocolate and molasses, but there are notes of roast, espresso, and even some light smoke.  The flavor is dry, and somewhat smokey with good amounts of dark chocolate, espresso, molasses, and roasted oats.  The body is medium with lighter than average carbonation and a long roasted and somewhat bitter dark chocolate finish.

big black colour, tan head and some lace. Big aromas of chocolate, espresso and a real oat sweetness as well. impressive. Big roasted espresso notes but it has a real creamy richness to it that i enjoy alot!
great brew!
Mildly sweet, smooth in every way.  Decent chocolate flavor, interesting Quebec ale.

Pours a solid black with a mocha/tan head that dissipates quickly leaving some lacing on the way down. Smells vinous with dried fruits like raisin plum and prune coming to mind. A bit of roast and chocolate hidden in there too. Tastes about like youd expect, A bit fruity some roast then some chocolate. Creamy to oily in the mouth. Crisp carbonation, solid body. Great brew Im impressed.
Really would like to try this again, pours big head, had on tap, dark in colour, looks like a typical stout, but it tasted watery, Im interested in trying this from a bottle, it had a decent taste
UPDATED: SEP 27, 2011 On tap. Big head on it. Aroma is very nice and typical. Taste and body are thin but still good. No real finish on it. I would like to try again.

Pours near black with virtually no head. Nose is quite sweet for a stout and the oatmeal quality is obvious, along with the usual roastiness. Flavor is a bit weaker than expected, again with obvious oatmeal. Hops and roastiness are light for a stout. Decent enough I suppose but not my bag.

Bottle poured a clear dark brown nearly black with a lasting brown head. Aromas of milk chocolate, licorice, roastiness, coffee, plum, fig and a hint of smoke. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of roasated malt, bakers cocoa, licorice, light coffee and light plum with a smooth dry lingering roasty finish.

Very nice jet black body with a decent level of dark head on top. Aroma is sweet barley, like fudge or caramel syrup. Flavour is sweet dark chocolate, coffee. Medium finish. This stuff is simple but excellent.

Old rate. Bottle from LCBO at Summerhill. Pours a dense black body with a thick kahki head. Lots of lacing. Aroma is of cocoa, roasted barley, and espresso beans. Bitter and roasty up front, leads into a subtle sweetness with hints of bitter-sweet chocolate and roasted coffee beans. Wonderful smooth milky mouth feel. Finishes roasty, and fairly bitter.

330ml bottle sample. Pours a dark brown closser to black, tan head nice retention, good lacing. Smells of caramel, chocolate. Tastes of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate. Just plain delicious, this may be the best product from this brewery. I highly recomend this beautiful beverage.
341ml bottle at Craigs house. Dark brown colour with a light head. A little thin but rather nice.

A great stout that has a near motor oil like pour that leaves a short creamy head.  The aroma is sweet while the primary taste is a very pleasant roasted malt.  I wouldnt describe the taste as complex but there are subdued hints of dark chocolate, toffee & coffee.   This is a very satisfying beer.  I wish I had a second bottle in the frig now.

A: snifter. Color is pitch black, similar to an abyss. Rich tan head. great retention. phenomenal lacing.

S: sweet roasted malty aromas. some coffee, caramel, and some toffee.

T: very mellow flavors. roasted coffee flavors, with some hints of oatmeal. no bitterness at all.

M: very smooth oatmeal stout, perhaps the smoothest I have tasted. silky mouthfeel with a very mild carbonation level.

D: extremely smooth and a great example of what an oatmeal stout should be.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2013 pours pitch black with a creamy beige-brownish head, excellent retention. coffee, roasted black coffee, tobacco. smokiness, black aged rum and dark chocolate. little sweetness at the end. short to medium long resinous finish. medium carbonation - not to its best when bottled. silky, almost syrupy feeling. full body. excellent stout - my go-to stout.
Light roast nose. Heavy coffee flavour, big round taste. Long lingering coffe with a hint of cocoa.

From the bottle, into a tulip cool but not chilled. Aroma of tar, rubber, burnt wood, doughy, buttered chocolate ganache, kelp and rust, confusing not enticing. Jet black, a wall of bubbles adhere to the glass, the head a sudsy tan mess that laces well. Raw sugar and smoke are my initial thoughts when tasting, some heavily roasted coffee, that ganache of the aroma at the rear and into the bitter, burnt malt swallow. Some tannins evident, a very strong linger of bonfire ash, quite harsh in flavour all in all. Body is quite light, its presence is huge though, the carbonation bitingly acidic. I need to swirl this until it is almost flat for it to be palateable. I have to go against the grain on this one, I just do not get its 100 status. Harsh, lacking balance and poise, and a little clumsy! (341mL, No date stamp, Dan Murphys Albany)

12 oz bottle.  Black pour brown head.  Nose is smoky and sweet malt.  Oatmeal hints.  Taste is big flat tart sweet with bitter smack in the back.  Not good.  Not smooth.  Guessing maybe bad bottle.  Will rerate when possible, but leaving here as place-holder.  Drain, here we come.

341ml bottle. Jet black pour with a solid mocha head that leaves a good ring of lace. Heavy coffee and dark chocolate notes with a hint of fresh hops. The same kind of profile in the mouth with a lingering dark chocolate finish. Superb.

Thanks to jrallen34 for this. Pours a near black with a tan head. Smell is initially a good amount of diacetyl. A little bit of hocolate and roasted malt in the background. Taste is quite similar wig some butterscotch. Tastes like a popcorn Jelly Belly. Not particularly good. Mouhfeel is medium. Drinkability is truly hampered by the off flavors.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-19-2010

Bouteille 341 ml. En fût. 5%. Couleur noire comme la nuit. Mousse beige, très crémeuse en fût. Bonne effervescence en bouteille qui est reliée à la façon de la servir en fût. Arôme de chocolat noir, espresso, houblon. En bouche, douce, pleine, le café et le chocolat amer se marient bien. Finale un peu amère. Du bonbon.
Draft: pours dark black with a thick tan head, malty aroma, roasted malt and mildly sweet taste, full bodied.

12oz bottle.Its a weird contradiction to wonder how this beer received a 100th percentile score both overall and by style while giving it a rating that supports those 100th-percentile scores. At first sip I didnt really think it scored that high. And if I were to rate by flavor alone, I wouldnt rate it so high. But as I filled in the numbers I realized its solid, crunchy, chewy flavor is very well augmented by its lovely roast-grain, toffee and caramel aroma, its dark inky appearance with creamy head that coats the glass with lace, its velvety-smooth palate, and its long, dark-grain and dark-stone-fruit aftertaste. It has all of the attributes one looks for in a great beer in general or a great stout in particular....... and yet I felt it was somehow less than the sum of its parts. It hits all the right notes except for that emotional note that makes me want to pick up more of it. This is the Lexus of beers: refined to such a degree that its perfection is practically sterile and boring. I want to give it a lower rating, I really do. But anyone who has driven a Lexus knows what I mean... you just cant badmouth the damn thing even if youd never want to own one.
Had one last night, bottled. Pitch black w/ brown head. Nice full flavour. Finishes nicely.

New Beer Distributors 4-pack ($7.25): Pours a black body over a more or less quickly dissipating head. Aroma is of wood, roasted malts, and I guess chocolate, although it wasnt as prominent for me as it was for other reviewers. Taste is slightly burnt, from the complex roasted malts. There is hop bitterness that interacts very well with the aforementioned taste. Bunch of oatmeal of course. I expected more coffee but didnt really get it from this beer.  Medium bodied, giving this beer a very smooth and creamy texture.

This starts with a full espresso/chocolate mouthtaste.  It doesnt bloom, but rather, moves directly to a strong hop-flavored finish.  I prefer that a stout (beer) that wants the hop finish arrive with at least some of the other flavors intact.  This does not.  Note: I first had this with a spinich/artichoke pizza in Ottawa.  Not a good combo.

Black with a finger of fairly fuzzy warm-brown head.  Aroma is chocolate with slight soy sauce and hop character.  Flavor is chocolate, bitterness, slight soy, slight coffee, very frothy carbonation on the palate.
At a tasting, thanks oren: honey, some black coffee, weak espresso, light-medium creamy body, some burnt wood, caramel, a bit of chocolate, some sourness, a bit of cocca, very nice.

At a tasting, thanks Oren, pours hazy dark brown with a chocolate head, aroma of chocolate, nuts, a bit of smokiness, plums and scotch, flavor is smoked with burnt wood, fireplace, dark chocolate and oatmeal, almost full bodied, excellent brew.

At a tasting, thanks Oren, smallish head, deep dark brown colour, smokey aroma with some roasted malt and light coffee notes, strong flavours of charred wood and smoke. long mellow charred bitter aftertaste. Not bad.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2012 Re-rate 4/9/12: Bottle shared at a tasting at Rotems place. Black-colored with a light brown head. Aroma of chocolate and a bit of dark fruits. Bittersweet flavor with chocolate, a bit of coffee and a drier finish. Medium-bodied. A nice Stout. 7/4/7/3/14=3.5

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks Oren. Dark brown to black-colored. Sweet aroma of chocolate, a bit of nuts, roastiness and light coffee hints. Sweet flavor with some chocolate, a bit of smoke and a slightly drier finish. Medium silky body. 7/3/7/4/14=3.5

Bottle. Almost opaque nearly black ale. Small brown head that slowly dissipates. Rich aroma of chocolate. Mild carbonation. Slight sweetness and fairly bitter chocolate flavour. Rich, thick velvety texture. Very nice.

I get cottage cheese and coffee on the nose.  Pretty straight forward aroma but very rich and present.  Flavor is light coffee and earthy roots or stalks of greens with a metallic twinge and again finishes with a acidic farmers cheese thing that lingers.  Great mouthfeel that is full and warming but still very clean which fits the slate powder like flavor.  Nice brew to try.  Thanks  McAusian Brewing.  2010 12oz.

(Bottle at Chris & Ruth, huge thanks) This was very nice oatmeal stout. The balance between roasted malts and sourness from oatmeal was right. Bitterness was quite low but it didnt disturb me. Aroma contained liquorice but it was missing from the taste. The long lasting aftertaste was mostly roasty.
Bottle pours a black beer with a thin brown head. Scent is sweet roasted malts and coffee. Taste is same as the scent.

Bottle, many thanks to the legend which is Jerc. Thanks, Jeremy. Poured into a pint glass. Epic and awesome lacing. Opaque; black tar colour, great colour of the lacing too, aroma of oats; cream, chocolate some oak perhaps? Taste is awesome. Loads of oatmeal, roasted malts, cream, rich guey chocolate, wood and oak. Wow what a combo. This is the BEST oat stout Ive ever had. This is fantastic. What an interesting and innovative blend. Maybe I should have had this baby for breakfast? Damn exceptional breakfast beer! So silky smooth and a little nutty on the palate
This beer is awesome in bottle but in draft it become like Christmas and new years eve in the same time, cereal, chocolate, coffee all in a good balance wow

Thanks to my father for picking up this beer while he was in Halifax.

The beer pours a black color with a tan head. The aroma is awesome. I get a lot of chocolate and coffee notes, with some cream notes as well. The flavor is a chocolate, coffee, roasted malt and cream. Low bitterness. The beer is very drinkable and doesnt have any bitterness from the coffee or roasted malt. Medium to thick mouthfeel and low carbonation. There is a ton of flavor in this beer considering it is only 5 percent. It has been a while since I have tried it, but this beer reminds me a lot of the Portsmouth Oatmeal Stout. Outstanding beer.

My favourite stout, bar none. Bottle LCBO Pours black with medium tan head. Pleasant aroma of sweet roast malts. Somewhat thin mouth feel but smooth and pleasant. Coffee and chocolate in the taste, quite complex. Dry finish. Beautiful.

This wasnt bad, but underwhelming for a stout...Looked great, but lacked body and mouthfeel, a lot of hops but not much oatmeal, and I didnt get any of the chocolate.  

Its not bad, but I think Im spoiled on stouts and this wasnt awesome.
UPDATED: OCT 18, 2010 Medium bitterness, very dark black color, small to moderate head, average carbonation, long finish, pronounced dark chocolate taste, medium coffee taste, great overall beer!

On tap at the Spitfire Arms in Nova Scotia. My second oatmeal stout, and I found it preferable to the first (Samuel Smiths). Looked very impressive, black, with a thick brown head, in a matching St. Ambroise  glass. Faint touch of oats in the aroma, tastes of chocolate and espresso.

The flavor has a whole bunch of elements going on in this one. There is some good chocolate,coffee notes. As well a good dose of oatmeal. Everything just goes well together

The aroma is big on the oatmeal front and some earthiness 


Pours a black color with a good size mocha head and a decent amount of lacing

It finishes with some bitterness. You get a mix of dark chocolate and some hops. This is by far the best Oatmeal stout i have had. Yet another great beer from these guys. So many things going on in this beer.
Very good Oatmeal stout all kinds of flavors going on. Coffee, chocolate, roasted. Some flavors I cant put me finger on. Serving: Bottle

UPDATED: APR 22, 2011 355mL courtesy of TheEpeeist. Pours a deep brown/ruby looking black in the glass with a massive rocky tan head that leaves excellent poofy lace. Aroma is red wine sulfides, red grape skins, big barbecue ribs, old world tar. Taste is very smokey, lots of barbecue all top of a fairly thin, watery body. 9/11/2010 6/5/7/3/13=3.4355mL. The pour is very deep brown to near black for a 5% beer. Head is massive, towering, giant mocha ice cream scoop. Awesome retention and big soapy lace. Aroma is heavy tiramisu right out of the glass, meat, smoke, sweet cherries, licorice, very muted by present old world tar and smoked village. Taste is oily up front moving to soapy and bitter in the mid and then oily and soft in the finish. Smoky aftertaste. What a treat for a normal stout. Definitely worthy of world class.

Bottle at St Stephens with Linh. Pours a deep murky black with a thick creamy brown head. Aroma is chocolate and sweet malty roast. Mouthfeel is full and creamy with notes of sweet rich chocolate, slight coffee roast and a touch of cinnamon in the finish.
Bottle. Pours black with tan head. Nose of roasted malts, oatmeal and chocolate. Little burnt coffee. Taste of espresso, burnt oatmeal, heavily roasted malts and chocolate. Dry finish.

Black pour with a thick tan head that clung to the sides.  Aroma of roast and smoke, toast, coffee, chocolate.  Creamy and rich bodied with char, coffee, chocolate, roast, a whiff of smoke.  There was an odd, wine-like character lurking as well.  Pretty impressed with the quality of this for the price.
Tried this beer after seeing the rave reviews here. This beer does not disappoint. Smells of dark chocolate, with expresso notes. Full bodied, almost a meal in a bottle, but is well balanced. Smooth.
Hello, very good beer along with Rickards Dark if you like the taste of a real beer.

Bottle. Pours thick black, respectable tan-colored head, some lacing. Nose has hints of chocolate, and a nice, sweet earthiness. Tastes like fine milk chocolate, oats, earth, and a tinge of dark fruits. Goes down smooth. Me likey.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2010 Bière dégusté en fut à la terrasse de la brasserie sur St-Ambroise. Belle couleur, très crémeuse du à lutilisation de lazote en fut vs CO2 en bouteille, peu mousseuse, bien houblonné et peu malté. Bon nez!

Pours a two finger brown head that fades slowly leaving some lace. Black with no highlights. Good carbonation and medium bodied.  Roasted chocolate nose. Flavor is a smoky, roasted chocolate. $3.45 for a 11.5oz bottle from Beverage Warehouse Winooski, VT.

On tap at the Queen and Beaver in Toronto, served in an English pint glass. Pours deep black with a tall, dense frothy light brown head. The head has great retention and leaves copious lace. On the nose, there are aromas of burnt malt, coffee, chocolate and smoke, along with hints of grass, grain and vanilla. The flavour begins moderately sweet with significant roasted notes and becomes slightly bitter and a little sour towards the end. The finish is average in duration and quite roasty. On the palate, it is full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent stout with a beautiful roasted nose and a nice hint of grassy hops. The appearance is beautiful and the flavour is delicious. 2010-08-22

I first tried this years ago during those rough experimental beer years.. a true gem. Lush and rich espresso malts with sweet dark chocolate notes. Pours rich and black with a proud head. A great stout to try and very common here in Canada.
Black. Creamy. Tan head. Really "dense". Chocolatey, a lot. Some coffee and smoke, with a hint of fruits which is even more obvious once in the mouth. The stout every stout would like to be.

[341ml bottle] Biere noire indeed  no light creeps through this one at all. Decent tan head that retains a while. Dark thick aromas, heavy malt, coffee and chocolate with something akin to ice-cream. Prime taste is bitter coffee, cant really taste any oatmeal. Some bitter smoke flavours as well. Nothing subtle about this, heavy coffee dominates  I dont drink coffee, so not one for me. As my friend said  Thats the stoutiest stout that ever stouted. [15/08/2009]

341ml bottle. It looks fantastic, pouring an opaque black, with a large tan head, and good lacing. The aroma mixes espresso with some sweeter milk chocolate notes. Initially there are some strongly bitter hops, soon shifting into an espresso flavour. In the middle this is joined by a slight hint of citrus - barely detectable, but it is nonetheless there. It finishes with bitter dark chocolate and a lingering milk chocolate aftertaste. In short, what this tastes like is a stout. It is a good example of the style, and definitely worth trying for those who, like me, love a good stout, however it just doesnt break out from being a good stout into being a truly great stout.

Freelance sampling at beerbistro in Toronto.  great looking stout in the mini snifter its served in.  tastes of bitter dark chocolate and burnt coffee yet is creamy and delicious.  not as heavy as other oatmeal stouts. so so good.  what a terrific saturday evening.

Bottle. Black. Mocha head. Overpowering aroma of burnt coffee and chocolate, taste similar. Sweet initially but turns slightly sour in the finish. Not on par with some of the better oatmeal stouts, but a good example of the style.

Aroma is full of roasted malt: burnt coffee, chocolate milk, whole grain toast, and toffee--a bit sour.
Opaque brown-black with filmy brown head and no lacing.
Sweet in front with a hint of sour from the chocolate malt, with a bitter malty finish.
Medium bodied, a bit light for the style, and somewhat overcarbonated, only slightly silky from the oatmeal.

Has a very dark pour with a off white foam head that is very faint and sparse. The aroma has notes of chocolate. oats, coffee, and malts. The carbonation is somewhat light and the flavors of chocolate and oats are present but not too prominent/overpowering. Its interesting and refreshing.

Bottle pour gives almost black color with thin very brief tan head.  Aroma roast and coffee.  Flavor is the strong point - very nice balance of coffee, malts, roast and chocolate.  Alcohol not apparent.  Finish smooth with no bitterness.  Mouth feel a bit on the thin side and detracts from what is otherwise a very tasty stout.

I really like the taste here, very drinkable stout.

Pours black with a nice mocha head. Aroma is of dark chocolate and coffee malts as well as some vanilla and toffee. Taste is of roasted malts; coffee and chocolate with a nice dry bitterness to it. Full bodied, thick and creamy with a lingering chocolate finish. Overall a very good stout, one of the best stouts Ive had.

Bottle from grocery store
Pours pitch black with very nice brown head, which remains. 
chocolate and coffee notes, hints of vanilla. Ive tried many other Oatmeal Stouts and this one always comes back as a point of reference. I can get a 6 pack for 7.99$ when on sale at local grocery store. An excellent beer.
UPDATED: JUN 14, 2010 Great beer with lots of flavours going on.  Taste of oatmeal, caramel, coffee.  Not too thick, actually somewhat watery... but very drinkable.  Definitely a "go to" beer.

Bottle.  Pours a deep dark black with a large creamy mocha head.  Very pretty.  Rich roast, sweet plum, vanilla and caramel, and faint hints of smoky coffee.  Creamy, nice roast.  Cocoa, light coffee, sweet oatmeal, really nice roast notes, but soft.  Soft smoky finish, lingering cocoa bitterness.

11.5oz bottle in an English pint.  Pours very dark brown with a thin brown head and some lacing.  Aroma of roasted malts, cereal, and a hint of coffee.  Average body and I was expecting a thicker beer for this style.  Flavors mainly of malts, but has a slight hoppiness to it.  Finishes with coffee and a hint of chocolate.  Pretty good for a stout, but I would like it to be a little heavier on the body.
One of the best stouts ive ever had. Ive spent a lot more money on stouts that werent as good. If you factor in the price it may be along with Bells stouts the best bang for your buck.

On tap at Sheraton Centre in downtown Montreal, in bottles in Brampton, ON.  6x341ml, $12.95 CAD

What can I say about this stuff other than its one of my all time favorites, top 5 for sure.  I fell in love with it on a visit to Montreal where it was on a tap at my hotel.  I immediately asked what it was and the bartender went into a whole "spiel" about how he thought it was better than Guinness... 

Aside from that, its a chocolate black ale that smells like chocolate, coffee grinds, and malt.  There are MANY tastes at work but for me:  roasted, toast, burnt, cofee, chocolate, malt, and either vanilla OR caramel but not both.  Im having a tough time deciding on which apparently..  

One of the best!
On tap at the Wooly.  Dark as night, cappucino head.  Awesome roasted malt, hint of coffee!  Great beer!
UPDATED: MAY 9, 2010 Aroma is of light caramel and coffee.  Taste is creamy, easy drinking with hints of bittersweet dark chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts on the aftertaste.  Finish is smooth

4 pack for $8.99. Pours very dense. Thumb sized head that stayed for about two minutes, then reduced to a lingering ring. Almost sweet aroma with notes of grapes, apricots, and caramel. Rich up front taste that lingers minutes after you drink it. Slight hoppy tinge that perfectly complements the taste. Would definitely buy again.

This one is really amazing on tap with the nitro, but still very, very good in a bottle (as sampled for rating). Use to have these all the time with bison burgers... excellent !! Pours a real black colour with a tiny bit highlights of red wine. The head is beige, huge, creamy, has great retention and leaves chunky lacing. The aromas are all over, with some roasted malts, grain malts, bananas, molasse and nuts. Goes down very smooth. The taste has the same flavours found in the nose, rosted malt, molasse, light fruits and some coffee and candy. A good bitterness kicks in, in the aftertaste. A very well-brewed and good balanced, excellent oatmeal stout.
Pours vey thick Black with a tan head, lacing on the glass. Sweet aroma,syrup/ molasses.Tastes thick malt, liquorice and treacle.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2012 Some beers are actually better in retrospect than in the moment. Others are great in the moment, but in retrospect you feel you romanticized it too much. However, in the case of St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout, its a beer that was equally great in the moment as it is in memory. A beer that leaves that kind of impact on your brain MUST be good, eh?POUR, COLOR AND AROMAThe beer poured smoothly and formed a thick layer of tan-colored, creamy head which lasted throughout the life of the drink and left some lacing on the glass. The body has all the makings of a classic stout with an opaque black body. No carbonation was noticeable, although the beer did appear to have a more viscous body just from the liquid and head alone. The aroma was light, sweet, and slightly malty. TASTEMost of my beer-drinking occurs after dinner, although many connoisseurs purposely drink with a meal to see how well it compliments. But, a beer like St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout is so sweet and rich that it works much better when drunk on its own, especially as a dessert alternative. This beer has a sweet, roasty taste with a distinct nutty finish. Chocolate, coffee and even a bit of vanilla flavors can be detected - which all combine for a savory palate. Its balanced out with a maltiness to make for a spectrum of great taste.FINISHSt. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout is one of the easiest brews Ive ever consumed, likely due to its overall robust body and seemingly low carbonation. It has a very soft mouthfeel despite maintaining a strong hops presence. However, it does leave a slightly bitter aftertaste in the mouth. BODYGreat beers like this just go to show just how heavy stouts arent. Im not sure of the number of calories and carbs, but I was able to drink two bottles back-to-back after a big dinner without feeling full or overwhelmed. And at only 5% ABV, St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout is the type of beer that could be consumed quickly, easily and in mass quantity (if only it came in six or 12-packs, rather than four-packs).FINAL THOUGHTSI have had sweeter and even tastier stouts, but its hard to find a quality stout that is this satisfying on so many levels. Thats what makes St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout such a great beer in my book.NOTE: watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bLzJH0TQAbc

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 pours a pitch black with a thick, creamy mocha head .  aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee. taste is loaded with dark chocolate, and lingers in a pleasant way for quite some time. medium bodied, and medium carbonation.  Delicious

pours a pitch black with a thick, creamy moka head that leaves tons of lacing throughout the beer. aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, some licoric and a bit of coffee. taste is loaded with dark chocolate, and lingers in a pleasant way for quite some time. medium bodied, and medium carbonation. this beer is well worth its value at 9 bucks for a 6 pack, and is widely distributed in the Montreal area. your perfect everyday beer.

341ml Bottle. Pours opaque, reflective black/brown. Subtle coffee, chocolate, roast and oatmeal aromas. Smooth mouthfeel with an almost citric finish on palate. Great value for the price of six. This drink is best served from two bottles. Definitely a well rounded beer you just want more of.

Pours dark ruby brown with a reddish brown head. The aroma is oatmeal, chocolate, raisins, brown sugar and a slight note of band aid. The flavor is smooth and dry with oats, berries, chocolate, and roast coffee. It has an ashy finish. A pleasant stout.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2010 Une fois dans le verre, son collet moka est bien haut et collant.  Le liquide est noir pétrole.  Au nez, les arômes sont complexes: café bien serré, chocolat amer, bois brûlé, mélasse, lointaine réglisse.
